translation: Two other small, dented photographs, likely taken the same year, show the same child, but smaller, in a ruffled dress and puffed sleeves.

In the first, she snuggles playfully against a large woman wearing a striped dress with her hair rolled up, while in the second, she raises her left fist and her right hand is held by a tall man wearing a light-colored vest and pants, with a casual posture.
The two photos were taken the same day in front of a wall adorned with a flower border, in a paved courtyard.
A clothesline runs above their heads, with a pin still attached.

Another photo, signed by the same photographer but with a more ordinary paper and lacking the golden border, likely intended for the same family distribution, shows a four-year-old girl, serious and almost sad despite a lively bunch of curls under a short haircut, pulled back by ribbons tied to barrettes, like butterflies.

Her left hand rests on the same carved Louis XVI-style table, fully visible, while her right hand is tucked into her bodice, her skirt pulled up in front due to a prominent belly, perhaps a sign of rickets (1944, approximately).
The boys were proud to leave for the regiment and looked handsome in their soldier's uniforms.
In the evening of the draft board, they went from café to café to celebrate their new status as real men.
Before the regiment, they were still just kids and weren't worth anything in the job market or in marriage.
Afterwards, they could have a wife and children.
The uniforms they wore on their leaves in the neighborhood were steeped in patriotic beauty and virtual sacrifice.
The shadow of the victorious soldiers, the GIs, hovered around them.
The rough fabric of the jacket, brushed against when standing on tiptoes to kiss them, symbolized the absolute divide between the world of men and that of women.
Seeing them filled one with a sense of heroism.

Under the immobility, the posters of last year's circus with Roger Lanzac's photo, the communion pictures distributed to classmates, Radio Luxembourg's Song Club, and the days filled with new desires.
On Sunday afternoons, we would crowd around the electricity store's window, watching TV.
Cafes invested in buying a set to attract customers.
The hillsides were filled with winding motocross tracks, and we spent all day watching the deafening machines.
The growing impatience of commerce, with its new buzzwords "initiative" and "dynamism," shook up the routine of the towns.
Between the funfair and kermesse fairgrounds , Quinzaine commerciale established itself as a springtime ritual in retail business.

In downtown streets , speakers blared out calls to buy things or win prizes cars like Simca or furniture for example interleaved by songs from very popular singers like Annie Cordy and Eddie Constantine .
One could also find stand-up comedians performing jokes that refered to famous French humorists Roger Nicolas or Jean Richard's acts while hosting game shows just like on radio stations .

The Queen of Commerce was seated at one corner on stage under her crown showcasing goods in festive spirit as people's aspirations changed because they didn't want their life routines fossilized avoiding seclusion at home.
But they only talked about what they had seen, which could be relived by eating and drinking.
They didn't have enough talent or conviction to talk about what they knew but hadn't seen.
So, no mention of Jewish children boarding trains to Auschwitz, or the dead collected in the morning in the Warsaw Ghetto, or the 10,000 degrees in Hiroshima.

Which is why the history lessons, documentaries, and films later on wouldn't dispel the impression that the crematoriums and atomic bomb were not part of the same era as black market butter, air raid drills, and descending into the cellar.
They were comparing the current war to the Great War, the one that took place in 14, the one that was won in blood and glory, a war of men that women listened to with respect.
They talked about the Chemin des Dames and Verdun, the gassed soldiers, the bells of November 11, 1918.
They named villages where not a single child who had left for the front had returned.
They contrasted the soldiers in the mud of the trenches with the prisoners of 40, who were warm and safe for five years and hadn't even received any bombs on their heads.
They argued over heroism and misfortune.

The children didn't listen and quickly left the table as soon as they were given permission, taking advantage of the general goodwill of the holidays to engage in forbidden games, jumping on the beds and hanging upside down from the swing.
But they retained everything.

Next to the fabulous time whose episodes they wouldn't put in order for a long time, the Debacle, the Exodus, the Occupation, the Landing, the Victory they found the nameless time, where they grew up, dull.
They regretted not being born, or barely, when they had to leave in droves and sleep on straw like gypsies.
From this unlived time, they would keep a persistent regret.
The memory of others passed on a secret nostalgia for this era that they had missed by so little and he hope of living it one day.
The frenzy that had followed the Liberation was subsiding.
People were now only thinking about going out, and the world was full of desires to be satisfied immediately.
Everything that constituted a first since the war was causing a rush, from bananas to National Lottery tickets, to fireworks.

Whole neighborhoods, from grandmothers supported by their daughters to babies in strollers, were rushing to the funfair, the torchlight procession, and the Bouglione Circus, where they were almost trampled in the crush.
They gathered in large, singing crowds along the road to welcome the statue of Our Lady of Boulogne and escort it back the next day over long distances.
Whether profane or religious, any occasion was good for them to be outdoors together, as if they wanted to continue living collectively.
On Sunday evenings, cars would return from the sea with young men in shorts singing at the top of their lungs, perched on the roof racks.
Dogs wandered freely and mated in the middle ofthe street.
Family and social narratives are one and the same.

The voices of the guests defined the spaces of youth: the countryside and farms where men had been apprenticed and women had served, the factory where they had all met, socialized, and married, the small businesses where the most ambitious had risen.

They sketched stories without personal events other than births, marriages, and deaths, without travels beyond the regiment in a distant garrison town, existences occupied by work, its hardship and wear, and the threats of alcohol.
School was a mythical background, a brief golden age whose ruler was the strict teacher with his iron rule for rapping on fingers.

From hand to hand, browned photos passed with tattered edges, stained by the fingers of all those who had held them at other meals, a mix of coffee and melted grease blending into an indeterminate color.
In the stiff and serious wedding guests, seated in rows along a wall, no one recognized their parents or anyone else.
It wasn't even oneself that one saw in the half-naked baby of indeterminate sex on a cushion, but someone else, a creature belonging to a silent and inaccessible time.
